Then my parents got divorced. My mother remarried - another rich guy. The thing is this one couldn't keep his hands off me. (a beat:) Bedtime stories were his speciality - sweetheart, lemme read you a story. Before I knew it he had his fingers in my cunt-- (uneasy) Look, you don't have to -

(sharp) Hey, you asked. (then: ) I told my mother, but she didn't believe me. Nobody believed me. When I was fourteen he tried to fuck me. That's when I split. (shrugs) No possessions. I travel light.
I'm really - She sits up abruptly -
What's that?
What's w-
Sssh! They listen. Dead silence except for crickets...

Les? Who's -?

She grabs 29.
Hey, once upon a time I was counted a pretty fair boxer... him -

This is no joke. He's out of his mind. He was in Viet Nam...Two tours of duty. He used to kill gooks and keep their ears on a string. Just... (she listens, then releases him) Maybe I imagined it. She sits on the bed, shaking. He puts an arm around her.

Jesus... Why does he follow you?
He's crazy, I told you. (then she gets to her feet and starts to dress) I've got to go.
(concerned) Stay.
No. (then:) No, I never stay.

ON FAUNIA--She wears shorts, high, rubber boots and a tee shirt, not exactly romantic, but on her the effect is curiously carnal. She moves through her morning routine o milking. She nudges a COW into position -  30.

C'mon Maggie, that's a good girl... (then: ) Move your ass, Flossie you old bitch. Suddenly Faunia realizes that she isn't alone; she looks smiles: COLEMAN SILK--Who knows how long he has been standing watching her;
(returning her smile) Hi... ON FAUNIA--She looks at him and nods; there is an unexpec dignity in her gaze.
(continuing) I, ah...got to thinking and...ah, when you reach my age it wouldn't hurt if I were to start drinking more milk. I mean... (embarrassed) Calcium--that sort of thing.
(amused) The milk's in that old fridge by the door. Leave a couple of dollars in the mason jar on the top.

Fine... Nevertheless, he doesn't move. CLOSE ON FAUNIA IN A SERIES OF DISSOLVES WE SEE: Faunia gently, but firmly shoving the cows into position. Come on, Daisy... After I left Boston, I was in Florida for a while, doing this and that.  31.
FAUNIA (cont'd) A girl like me can always get by. Hand me that hose - the red one- Coleman hands it to her - enchanted by her sensual moveme as she goes about her work... her hands...

(continuing) Then I got tired of that, came up here and married - guess what - a dairy farmer. Lester Farley. I was 20... (she looks at Coleman who is watching her) What are you looking at? CLOSER ON COLEMAN--Hew smiles, shrugs. TIGHT ON FAUNIA--She returns the smile, then goes back to work.

(continuing) I remember one time we got in this huge fight in the barn and I threw cow shit at him. He threw cow shit back at me; next thing you know we're both covered in cow shit and laughing like hell. Best day of the marriage.
(more to make conversation than anything) You never had kids?
(a beat:) No. No kids.
CLOSE ON LESTER FARLEY-~He is the same man who we saw in opening sequence, sitting in the truck; the same man who Coleman Silk and Faunia off the road.
Did you ever kill anyone in Vietnam, Mr. Farley?  32.

(he looks around amused) Did I kill anyone? (taking out a pack of cigarettes) Wasn't that what I was supposed to do when they sent me to Vietnam? Fucking kill gooks? They said everything goes so...I guess everything went. You have a match? A moment later someone from 0.S. hands him a pack of matc

(continuing; good manners) Thanks. (he lights his cigarette, inhales) Look, let's get something straight right off the bat, I never hurt her, okay? Never. And I never hurt the kids. That was all lies. She never cared about anyone but herself. I should've never let her go off with the kids. She-- (interrupting himself You sure you don't mind me smoking?
Not at all.

She waited until I was in rehab. That's why she wanted to get me in rehab to start with, so she could take the kids. She used the whole thing against me to get the kids away. She had no right to steal my kids. And now she's fucking this old Jew. (quietly) I should've killed her back then.
Coleman has taken to Faunia to a candlelit dinner at a Ne England gourmet inn. Faunia is nicely dressed; Coleman we a tie.  33.
(uneasy) I don't know why we had to do this...
(smiles) It's a meal, not a commitment.
(suspicious) Have it your way.
Hope I'm not late... They look up. It's Nathan. TIGHT ON FAUNIA--She turns to Coleman with the look of ‘a animal caught in a trap.
(to Nathan) We just got here. (to Faunia, ignoring her look) Faunia, I'd like you to meet my friend Nathan.
Hi. He extends his hand, which she ignores, glaring at Colema Nathan sits, recovering, just then the maitre'd appears hovering at Faunia's shoulder.
(handing her a menu) Madame the specialty of the house is game... (pointing) Perhaps the venison. Silence.
(continuing) Or perhaps Madame would prefer the fish. In that case I would recommend this... (pointing to one item on the menu) Or this...  34.
35 36 She slams the menu into the waiter.

Whatever he's having... (indicating Coleman) Ditto for me. QUICK CUT NATHAN--as he suddenly realizes that Faunia can read. TIGHT ON FAUNIA--who interprets Nathan's avoidance of his friend's gaze correctly.
(continuing) That's right, Mr. Zuckerman. I can't read. And she's out of there. Coleman is on his feet now -
Coleman -
(going after her) Look, I'm sorry -
Another time...
Right... Nathan sits alone at the table set for three...
Coleman pursuing Faunia as she storms into his VOLVO. As Coleman climbs into the driver's side,
She's staring straight ahead...
Full of surprises, aren't you?
Take it easy. He's my friend, okay? I wanted you to get to know one another.  36 37 38 35.

Because you're so proud of me, right? (lighting a cigarette) You've really come down in the world, haven't you? Dean of Faculty, professor of classics - and look at you, fucking a cleaning lady who can't. even fucking read..! Coleman says nothing. There's nothing he can say.
(continuing; her voice. quiet) You're going to drop me now, aren't you?
Why are you always-
Because you're not up to fucking somebody who can't read. That's what you were thinking - It's exactly what he was thinking, but Coleman kisses her hard, his hands on her breasts.
You're wrong. I'm going to fuck you extra hard because you can't read.
(throaty laugh) Now you're talking.

TO REST ON THE RED PICK UP. It moves slowly around the co of the barn, lights off, and comes to a stop facing the house, the motor idling.  38 39 40 36.

THE CAMERA MOVES INTO A CLOSE SHOT OF FAUNIA as she comes wid awake. In the distance we hear the sound of Lester's truc idling. Her sudden motion brings Coleman awake.
What is it? What's wrong?
(a whisper) It's Les. He's out there. I can hear the truck. In the silence we can hear the engine of the truck as Les revs the engine slightly. Coleman grabs for his trousers.
I'll take care of this.
(panic) No, don't! He's crazy. But it is too late. Coleman has his trousers on and is pulling a sweater over his head.
As we watch, the high beams of the truck are turned on. A moment later Lester Farley appears in front of the truck silhouetted against the glare of the headlights.
(yelling) Come out of there you murdering bitch! ON THE DOOR--as it opens and Coleman steps outside holdin tire iron.
Come here you. I wanna talk to you! CLOSER ON LES: locking eyes with Coleman.  37.

Did she tell you?! Did she?! I bet not! (shouting so Faunia can hear) I bet you fucking didn't! (back to Coleman) Did she tell you she was giving some guy a blow job while her kids were catching fire? Did she?
Get out of here before I brain you!
Put that fucking thing down before I ram it through your fucking skull!

Les! TIGHT ON LES--He stops, looks at her. At the sight of her face suffuses with pain. HIS POV: Faunia stands just outside the door, now she is wearing Coleman's shirt and baggy work pants. She holds u revolver for him to see.

You murdering, fucking cunt! In the distance we hear a police siren approaching.
Get the fuck away from here. Just then a squad car with lights and sirens roars up. CLOSE ON LES~-He freezes. ON THE SQUAD CAR--The doors open and two cops race toward Les.
He swings 38.

Come on, Les...
Watch out -! at one of the cops, two more grab him from behind. He struggles but to no avail.
Fucking payback for what I did in 'Nam -! The COPS have tackled Les but it isn't easy. They wrestle to the ground and drag him to the squad car.

(continuing) Rehab again, right?! Thorazine for breakfast, right?! Fucking government. This is the fucking thanks I get for serving my country--for all the shit I went through. (as they drag him back towards the police car) They didn't give us a fucking chance. They say we lost the war. We didn't lose the war, the fucking government lost the war. I walked the walk, man. You can't know the shit I've seen. And then I come home to this! The COPS have reached the squad car, they open the back d VERY TIGHT ON LES--as they force him into the back seat, stares at his wife with a terrifying ferocity.
(continuing) Fucking a goddamn carpenter while her kids are on fire! I shoulda killed you and my kids when I had the chance - ! As the door slams, blocking him from view, we CUT TO:  39.
Faunia sits on the edge of the bed, shivering. Coleman is beside her, saying nothing, watching her patiently. Final

(continuing; clutching it to her breast, rocking it) I can never figure out what to do with them. Keep them? Bury them? My sole remaining "possession" and I don't know what to do with it. But it wasn't. Not by a long shot.

Lisa, darling, it's Dad...how's it going...? What? I can't hear you.  42 43 40.

Lisa, at her cluttered desk, filled with paperwork. She's attractive, with her mother's important hair but without Iris' aura of authority. Lisa is always overwhelmed. And just now upset as well, curt...

You don't sound fine. (no reply) How's the class coming? (smiles) What happened to the little kid who couldn't recognize the letter N? Did he ever get it? Lisa?
Everything's fine.
(frowns) Would you care to know how I am?

(vague premonition) Do you? She's staring into space, passing a hand over her forehea

text: Everyone knows you're exploiting an abused illiterate woman half your age. REVERSE ON NELSON PRIMUS, Coleman's attorney, an amiable fellow in his thirties; he wears a suit that hints of Ral Lauren more than Brooks Brothers. Nelson rapidly rereads letter, mumbling the words together-
"Evéryone knows you're exploiting an abused illiterate woman half your age." A grim smile as he sets aside the letter and looks O.S.:
(continuing) Well, if this doesn't take the cake- CROSS-CUT TO COLEMAN--pacing back and forth in front of h attorney's desk.
That's not all; my kids have even got wind of it.
You don't say...
What's more, I know damn well who wrote this - Delphine Roux.
Who?
Professor of Languages and Literature. (irate) I hired her for Christ's sake! I hired all of them..!
Why would she send you something like this?
I've no idea. How should I know? You're my lawyer. I want you to send her a letter and warn her off.
She'll just deny she ever -
That's her writing! Any handwriting expert would con-
You're being hasty -
No! No I'm not -
Yes you are, same as when you resigned from the college, just as the whole "Spooks" thing was on the point of blowing over. I told you then -
And I told you: they killed my wife! What else could I-?
Coleman. Slow down. SIT. Reluctantly, Coleman obeys. Nelson studies him.
(continuing) Listen to me, professor. Forget about the letter. You got bigger fish to fry. What are you going to do about Lester Farley?
Get a restraining order, an injunction, I don't know...

A restraining order. Have you any idea what you're getting into here, Coleman? What it looks like from the outside? (leaning back in his chair) After thirty-some years of academic distinction ina community you virtually created from scratch, suddenly you've gone off the deep end. You want me, to fight a legal war for you on two fronts - one of them with a phantom correspondent and the other with a psychotic who's been locked up twice in the mental ward at the VA hospital in Northampton, under real restraints, not legal ones. Before Coleman can get in a word -

(continuing) Sure I can get a restraining order, but will that restrain him? I can get you a handwriting expert. I can get you a bulletproof vest. But what I can't provide is what you're never going to know as long as you're involved with this woman: a scandal-free, Farley-free life. Is she HIV negative, by the way? Did you have her tested, Coleman? Did you use a condom, Coleman? And if you don't use protection, does SHE? How do you know she doesn't want to use you to help make up for what she's lost? Do I represent you in the paternity suit, Coleman?
I can handle Lester if I have to-
But why do you have to? Give up the girl, Achilles. 43. 44
(stiffening) I beg your pardon?

(grins) I took your intro to European lit umpteen years ago as an undergrad. Never forgot your lectures on Homer. Achilles, listen to me: you have to give up the girl. Give her up and your troubles go away. I'm speaking as your friend as well as your attorney. Faunia Farley is not in your league and she's not from your world. Last night you got a good look at her world - Coleman, the fact is she ain't worth it. (a amiable smile) Achilles on Viagra - how much sense does that make anyway? Coleman looks up at him - he's pale with fury. But when h speaks, it is with deadly quiet -
Are you quite finished? The tone gives Nelson pause. Coleman rises to his feet.
(continuing) You're a genuine vocal master, Nelson. And so rich with contempt for every last human problem you've never had to face.
Listen, I was only -

You listen: I never again want to hear that self-admiring voice of yours - or see your smug, lily white face. And with that he turns and stalks out. We HOLD ON THE OPE DOOR to the outer office as Nelson's secretary sticks her head in.
Is anything wrong, Mr. Primus?  44 45 45.
ON NELSON--he stands looking after Coleman.
(to himself, perplexed) What the hell do you suppose he meant by, "lily white." WHAM! The SOUND of a PUNCH: landing -!

TIGHT ON AN IRISH KID--big, although he cannot be more th eighteen as he takes the jab, blinks in surprise; then la out in a fury. TIGHT ON THE YOUNG COLEMAN SILK--aged 17 as he easily ste away from his opponenent's punch, feints with his left an slams a right hook into the Irish kids mid-section. Note: As Coleman boxes, we notice the barest trace of a s on his face; he knows just how good he is.

THEN IN A SERIES OF VERY QUICK CUTS we watch as Coleman b in on his opponent, easily dancing out of the way each ti the other boy tries to throw a punch. Over this we SUPERIMPOSE: "EAST ORANGE, NEW JERSEY 1944." Then, as the bell rings we CUT TO: WIDER ANGLE--We see we're in a GYMNASIUM, where a group o twenty-five or thirty men have crowded around a boxing ri cheering on the two young men. IN COLEMAN'S CORNER, DOC CHIZNER, Coleman's coach. A Dent in his 50's, Doc coaches kids but also referees big match in Madison Square Garden. Coleman, covered with sweat, breathing hard returns to his corner, drops onto a stool.
Coleman, wait for it! Wait for it! Let him do the work...Ah..! As Doc and the CUTMAN work him over:
(continuing) Listen to me, kid. You're smarter than him, you read me? Smarter. He's a putz. You counter punch. (tapping him on the side of the face) Coleman, pay attention...  45 46 46.
Coleman, breathing deeply, staring at his opponent across ring, nods.

(continuing) Counter punch. That's your game. Just then the bell sounds. Coleman charges out. As Doc watches, Coleman puts his strategy to devastating effect -it's like previews of Mohammed Ali. Coleman danci away, dodging the punches - he's enjoying himself, enjoyi using his brains in this brawny situation... bobbing and weaving. And then - WHAM! the counter punch from nowhere. the Irish kid drops to his knees.
ON THE DOOR--as it opens and the young Coleman, carrying gym bag in one hand and a stack of books in the other, st out. He holds the door open for Doc Chizner.
Next week, West Point...
(worried) Doc, that guy's got five pounds on me. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH THE TWO MEN as they walk towards D Chizner's car.
(confident) But he's slow. You can take him easy. Besides the Pitt coach is gonna' be there. He's a buddy of mine. I want him to see you fight.
So? They walk in silence for several beats, then:
So, once he sees you fight and once I tell him about your grades, I'm pretty sure he'll offer you a scholarship to Pitt.
(shakes his head) I can't go to Pitt. My father wants me to go to Howard.  47.
He's an optician, your dad?

Used to be, he lost his business in the depression. By now they have reached Doc Chizner's car. . boc Look, Coleman, just box for the guy. That's all. Then let's see what happens. He starts to get into the car, stops, turns back to Colem
(continuing; embarrassed to be saying this) One thing. When you meet the guy from Pitt, don't tell him you're colored, okay?
Don't tell him?
Don't bring it up. You're neither one thing or the other. You're Silky Silk. That's all.
He won't know?

How's he gonna know? Here's the top kid from East Orange High and he's with Doc Chizner; he's gonna think you're Jewish. And with that, Doc gets into the car and drives away as w HOLD ON YOUR COLEMAN watching the car disappear a thought look on his face.

TRACKING WITH COLEMAN--as he races down the alleyway, pus his way through a back gate and dashes up a short stairca two steps at a time. ON THE BACK DOOR--where his sister ERNESTINE, a light ski African American girl of fifteen is waiting for him.  47 48 49 48.
(an urgent whisper) You're late!
As Coleman pushes through the door, hands Ernestine his g bag.
I know. Hide this for me willya- THE CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they walk through the kitch toward the dining room.
Walter's home on leave -!

ON THE DOOR--as Coleman steps through the door into the dining room; it is attractively but inexpensively furnish Framed reproductions of flower painting and landscapes ar the walls. THE CAMERA PANS ACROSS TO THE DINING TABLE where the Silk family sits at dinner. Coleman's parents are light-skinne African Americans. Coleman's MOTHER is a primly attractive woman who sits ve straight in her chair - a nurse by profession. Coleman's FATHER is a barrel-chested man with intelligent features. He wears a tasteful, but inexpensive suit. The atmosphere in the room has a definite chill. ON COLEMAN--as he takes a seat next to his brother WALTER who is wearing a spiffy army uniform -
Sorry, I'm late-- ON COLEMAN'S FATHER--who says nothing, doesn't look up at son.
(coming to Coleman's rescue) What's this I hear about you being class Valedictorian? Mr. Silk continues to eat, saying nothing. Walter throws glance toward Coleman. Coleman shrugs.  49.
Just then Ernestine enters the room having stashed Colema gym bag somewhere.
Hey, with the only four point o grade average, who else were they--
Yes, we're very proud of Coleman. Nothing. Mr. Silk doesn't bother to look up.
(icy) May I inquire how you did, Coleman? TIGHT ON COLEMAN--again he shoots Walter a look, this tim Walter shrugs.
How I did?
Night before last, at the Knights of Pythias arena. I'm asking whether you won or lost your bout.
(furious, to Ernestine) Did you tell them? However before she can reply:
Kindly answer my question.
(glum) I won.
(like a prosecuting attorney) And how many fights have you won so far?
(quiet) Eleven.
And how many have you lost?
None, so far.
(acid) And when are you planning on turning professional?
(coming to Coleman's defense) Dad, he's only--
(not bothering to even look at Walter) This does not concern you, Walter. (to Coleman) I asked you a question, young man.
(eyes averted) Doc says I could get an athletic scholarship, maybe to Pitt.

Like Walter, you will go to Howard. And after Howard, should you choose to become a doctor, you will not be doing your hands any good, pummeling them in a boxing ring. (getting to his feet) You know, if I were your father, Coleman, you know what I'd tell you now?
You are my father.
I'm not at all sure. I was thinking that Doc Chizner was your father.
He's my coach, that's all. He teaches me how to fight. You're my father.
Well if I were your father, you know what I'd tell you now?  Sl.
(his voice a whisper) What.
I would say, "You won last night. Good. Now you can retire undefeated." (firm) You're retired. (getting to his feet) Now, if you'll excuse me, I don't want to miss my train.
Filled with DINERS and uniformed WAITERS bustling among w tablecloths, Mr. Silk, among them, carrying an overloaded TRAY.
Boy, this fish is overcooked...
Sorry, sir...
I'd like to change my order...

Yes, sir, very good, sir,... He picks up the man's plate, puts it on the laden tray al with food, glasses and utensils, starts back to the galle Suddenly he collapses, bringing down dishes with a CRASH! that startles everyone in the dining car.

A dreary spot. A knot of MOURNERS across from Mr. Silk's coffin. Mrs. Silk upright as always, her hair now tinged with GREY, a handkerchief to her mouth, holds Ernestine's hand. Ernestine's tears stream silently down...  51 52 52.

"Cowards die many times before their deaths; the valiant never taste of death but once." Clarence Silk knew well those lines from Julius Caesar. But I don't think there's any question here about who was valiant. PAN TO COLEMAN, stunned - The coffin now lowered into the ground...
Ashes to ashes...
At first we don't know where we are. Then a DOOR is opene revealing a SILHOUETTE -
Coleman?
Leave it off...Please...

Alright. She closes the door and walks tentatively towards Coleman who lies in his bed. Gradually, our eyes become accustome the dark; his mother sits on the edge of the bed. She's in her crisp, starched white NURSE'S UNIFORM -
You on duty? Tonight?
It's better this way. For me, anyway...
I never knew him. Not really. I didn't have any idea what he went through. Every... (on the verge of saying "godamned" but checks himself in front of his mother) ...Single day...
I don't believe he wanted you to know, dear. He couldn't see the point.
I can see the point. The point is if you're Colored it doesn't matter how much you know, you work in the dining car. That's the point.
Coleman, if it's your education, you don't have to worry. Your father's insurance and your own academic record will see to it that you get into Howard.
Mom, Howard isn't ‘a real university. Howard's no different from East Orange.
(sharp) Coleman!

(he must make himself heard, despite the cost) I heard all about Howard from Walt. He said they're always talking about "the negro people." About "We the negro people." Mom, I'm not a "political" person. I don't know who this "we" is.
Your father wanted you to know who you were; to be proud of your race.
(with passion) What about me?! What about just being proud of being me? I don't want to be part of some group. I don't want to be "a Howard Negro."
Coleman, your father wanted the best for you. He--  54.
And what about what I want?! It's my life! Don't I get any say in the matter? (softening his tone) Mom, I just want a chance to be the best I can be. Why is that so wrong?
I'm ‘not clever enough to argue with you, Coleman...
(he puts an arm around her) Then don't. Don't let's argue. I love you, Mom, but don't ask me to go there...
Coleman... you're barely eighteen; what're you going to do?

PAN THE ROOM TO RE A large CALENDAR with the date - October 6, 1944 and seve propaganda POSTERS which inform us that "There's still a to be won" in the Pacific, "One down, One to Go" etc. DISCOVER COLEMAN staring at his application form. NATHAN, who looks up from the letter, which he has just r

Coleman, I know it's bullshit, I'm your friend, remember ~-? Coleman bangs down the glass of ice tea -
Then act like it.
Coleman, don't take these people on. (gesturing toward the television where the impeachment hearings are playing) They're all crazy to blame, crazy to punish-
So I just throw her to the wolves? (Realizes) She's waiting for that. To her, sex and betrayal are as basic as bread.
I'm not thinking about her. I'm thinking about you. But Coleman is cranking up...

(continuing) Uh oh, we've got to run. He's pulling Faunia away but Nathan can't help himself.
Coleman!
I'll call you! As he hurries her away into the crowd we HEAR:  718 719 80 85.

I tried to use my imagination - not to speculate where they went. That wasn't hard. But rather to ponder what their mutual rage had made of them: outcasts, alone together, they were now stripped down to the simplest version of themselves. With nothing between them and their destiny.
CLOSE ON FAUNIA-~-as she leans over, kisses Coleman.
I have to go.
Stay here tonight. She shakes her head, smiles...
How many times do I have to tell you... (kissing him again) I never stay the night. Although she has said this many times, her heart isn't in
(leaning forward to kiss her gently) Just this once. We FADE TO BLACK:

ON COLEMAN--He sits at the kitchen table, reading the New York Times. A cup of coffee is in front of him and laid o on the table is an elegant breakfast: orange juice, toast a silver toast rack, eggs benedict (in a covered plate to keep them warm). He looks up, smiles.
(cheerfully) Good morning. REVERSE ON FAUNIA--She stands in the doorway, wearing sweatpants and a worn tee shirt.  86.
(continuing) Sit down, your eggs will get cold. Faunia sits; she has the look of an animal whose instinct sense a trap.

(continuing; making conversation) Doesn't look like Monica is going to find a job in New York any time soon. Faunia stares at the plate in front of her - HER POV - beautifully prepared eggs benedict... Coleman r
(continuing) "According to Vernon Jordan--
Can't you avoid the fucking seminar?
(looks up at her) I was only - Faunia hurls her cup of coffee across the room, shatterin and its contents against the cabinets -

I don't give a fuck that poor Monica can't find a job! Does fucking Monica worry if my back hurts from milking those fucking cows? Does she worry about me sweeping up people's shit at the fucking post office? You think losing your job when you're about to retire anyway is a big deal, it's not, I hate to-tell you. Having your step-father put his fingers in your cunt, that's a big deal; a husband who comes up behind you with an iron pipe and hits you in the head that's a big deal...having two kids suffocating and dying, that's a big deal!  87.

81 82 83 84 FAUNIA (cont'd) (tears starting) Shit... (looking around like a trapped animal) Why did I fucking stay?! It was a mistake. Even fucking whores know better: "Men don't pay you to sleep with them. They pay you to go home." And she runs out of the house and leaving him alone.

The same twisting two lane we saw at the start. Faunia's Chevy squealing around curves... The Chevy passes the SIGN at the head of a dirt road: AUD SOCIETY - where Coleman first gave her a lift. Her big ca squeals to a STOP out of FRAME.
Faunia leaning on the wheel, thinking. Crying.

A gray-shingled two story house nestled in the woods. WIN CHIMES. Once a residence, now the start of trails into th bird sanctuary... Faunia's Chevy bumps uncertainly into the parking area an stops. Faunia gets out, walks to the door.
CLOSE ON A CAGE with a crow (PRINCE) inside; he moves bac and forth in an excited manner.
Hi Prince... THE CAMERA WIDENS IT'S ANGLE--and we see Faunia approachi the cage and the bird getting as close to her as it can.
(softly) How are you doing my Prince? ON A DOOR LEADING TO THE OFFICE--inside a young girl is feeding an animal; she sees Faunia, who is obviously a regular visitor.  88.
Oh, hi. (nodding toward the cage) He got out the other day.
But he always comes back, don't you, boy? Can I have him on my shoulder? Honey, it's Faunia... The Bird watches her from within its cage.
You can try, but he won't come out of his cage if he thinks you want him to - Faunia opens the cage and holds out her hand, but Prince won't budge -

Oh, I know all his little tricks, don't I, Prince? (over her shoulder) He was famous in Seely Falls when I lived there, used to go for all the bright objects in the parking lot, barrettes in the girls' hair, keys and tin foil. The newspaper wrote him up... all about the folks who raised him after the nest was destroyed...one.
Yeah, we used to have the article on the bulletin board, but he pecked it all to pieces...
(laughs) He tore up his clippings? Ashamed of your background? Didn't want anyone to know about your past? Oh, you good boy, you good crow...
He was flying around outside like I said, but the other crows started attacking him - they would've killed him. He doesn't have the right voice.  89.
It's from being hand raised... (stroking the bird's breast) Hanging around all his life with people like us. The human stain... Suddenly Prince erupts in his own strange CAW -
See, he imitates the school kids who come here, but it's not the crow language and they catch on. Prince is a crow that doesn't know how to be a crow. Careful, he bites.
Oh, I know. Listen, he's humming! Listen, children... oh, children... CLOSE ON FAUNIA--to THE CAMERA:

The first time I tried was a month after they died...Oh, I was ecstatic, getting myself ready, that first time...I tried so hard... I was so happy. I remember the gin and the valium and the rat poison. It tasted bitter so I folded it into the butterscotch pudding... I was so happy... Why did they break down the door? I still don't know who did that, who ruined it... The second time my heart wasn't in it. It was just impulse and I slashed. TIGHT ON THE BIRD--watching her.
You remember, don't you, boy... ON FAUNIA--leaning close to the cage, whispering to the b
This morning I made a mistake. (she takes a last look) Farewell, my Prince.  90.

ESTABLISHING SHOT--The travelling wall (a reproduction of Vietnam Memorial in Washington) has been set up outside a shopping mall in Pittsfield. There are a number people (family members along with Veterans)seaching for the name comrades or relatives who were killed in action. In spite the fact that it is a large crowd it is more quiet than y would expect as people move about, talking quietly among themselves... From the distance we héar a speaker.
The people whose names are inscribed on this wall are your relatives, friends and neighbors. As the speaker continues we CUT TO: CLOSE ON THE WALL (TRACKING SHOT)--Row upon row of the na of the dead.

head_text.subj: ON LES, BOBCAT AND LOUIE, (TRACKING WITH THEM)

text: What's Kenny's last name? Nothing. Les is mesmerized by the wall.
Les?

(continuing) Peterson. Kenneth Peterson... What FOLLOWS is a MONTAGE as we see couples, their arms around one another looking at the wall. A child placing a small boquet of flowers by the wall. A man about fifty, kneeling beside the wall his hand resting against the wal though it held some magical power. And all the time we continually CROSS-CUT TIGHTER AND TIGHTER ON THE NAMES. TIGHTER AND TIGHTER ON LESTER FARLEY. Finally THE CAMERA COMES TO REST ON KENNETH BRIGGS.
(nodding 0O.S.) He's right over there, Les. Lester Farley doesn't move.
(continuing; quietly) Kenny's right over there; he's waiting for you.  85 86 91.

Finally Les crosses to the wall, stands in front of Kenny name for a long beat, then drops to his knees. JUMP CUT IN TIGHT ON LES as he touches the letters a spas pain crosses his face; then he leans forward and kisses t name. ON LOUIE AND BOBCAT--deeply moved.
(continuing) I told you the Wall would work. He's gonna' be okay. (tears in his eyes) Les is gonna' be okay, now...
Coleman enters and reacts - Faunia is there. She's cleaned the whole place, putting a saucepans and wiping off the coffee-stained cupboard from morning's debacle.
Hi...
Hi... Custodial Staff... Just doing my thing... He says nothing.
(continuing) Where were you?
I went to the movies. Another pause.
I'm sorry. For what I did. For what I said.
You were right. What happened to me is nothing.
They took away everything you had, everything you did - all over one stupid word... That isn't nothing.  92.

87 FAUNIA (cont'd) Anyways, I don't think you can measure sorrow... They've drifted towards one another; she's in his arms. T stand in the middle of the kitchen, holding one another. VERY CLOSE IN: Coleman's head rests against Faunia.
(a whisper) Can you keep a secret?... She pulls away, takes his head between her hands,
Later. As she kisses him we DISSOLVE TO:
ON THE PICK-UP TRUCK--It is parked by the side of the roa the lights are off; it sits silent and ominous in the gra light just before dawn. Over this we HEAR:
(exhausted) Numb. Fuckin' numb. No emotions. As Lester Farley continues THE CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES IN ON TRUCK.

(continuing) Numb to the death of my own kids. Vietnam. That's why I never did cry for my kids. He was five and she was eight. She was a stranger, my little girl. That fucking Vietnam, you caused this. My feelings are all fucked up. I said to myself, "Why can't I feel?" I said, "Why didn't I save them? Why couldn't I save them?" I kept thinking about Vietnam. About all the times I think I died. By now we are close enough to see the silhouette of leste Farley, slumped down on the driver's side. He lights a cigarette and for an instant we see his face.  87 88 89 90 93.

(continuing) That's how I began to know I can't die. Because I died already. LESTER'S POV; (TELEPHOTO SHOT): In the distance, from aro a turn we see the lights of a car approaching. It is the identical shot from the opening of the film.

(continuing) Because I died already in Vietnam. TIGHT ON LESTER--he leans forward, turns on the ignition ON THE TRUCK--as the headlights turn on. Again, it is the identical shot from the opening of the film. As the truck pulls away we CUT TO:
Nathan asleep, is awakened by the telephone. Groggily, he fumbles for the receiver.
Hello..? As he listens we hear from the distance, "Bewitched, Both and Bewildered." playing on the radio:
WIDE SHOT--It is a summer night, Coleman and Nathan are dancing. Over this we HEAR:
I hear that and everything within me unclenches and the wish not to die, never to die is almost too great to bear.

ON A GRAY SKY--we see crows circling overhead THE CAMERA DOWN past a frozen waterfall; in the F.G. is a precipice where a handful of people have gathered. THE CAMERA COMES REST ON NATHAN ZUCKERMAN standing at the edge of the crow HIS POV: of the mourners. A small woman with granny glass (SALLY) is speaking.  94.

We all lived with Faunia up at the farm and that's why we are here this morning, to celebrate a life. Faunia Farley was, as you know, a deeply spiritual person. As Sally's eulogy continues we PAN ACROSS TO NATHAN who i looking O.S. HIS POV:Among the mourners we notice an older, aristocrat looking couple (FAUNIA'S MOTHER AND STEP-FATHER); she wea a fur coat, he is perfectly groomed. They look very out o place.

Not a word about the accident itself. And certainly not a word to suggest what I knew without a doubt - that it had been no accident. CLOSE ON A PAIR OF HANDS--holding an urn; as we watch it tipped and Faunia's ashes spill out into the river below; moment later the box containing the ashes of Faunia's children is held up and it is overturned as well.

location: NORTH HAMPTON VA HOSPITAL CONFERENCE ROOM

text: We see a blank wall, the lighting is flourescent and institutional. In the FOREGROUND we see Lester Farley. He being interviewed by a PSYCHOLOGIST. What we are watching videotape.
They thought the Wall had saved me, but I faked them out. Use my vehicle, that was the plan. Along the river, come right at them, same lane... suicide mission...
At what point did you get in your truck?
This is all confidential, right?
Ummm. . .
After dark.
Silence. 95. 91
Had you had dinner?
No dinner.
Why did you get in the truck?
To get him.
To get who?
The Jew professor.
Why were you going to get him?
Because I had to.
Why did you have to?
(continuing) You were going to kill him.
Oh, yes, all of us.
There was planning then.
No planning.
You knew what you were doing?
Yes.
But you didn't plan it.
No.
With that the screen suddenly goes black and we CUT TO: (2)
Did you think you were back in Vietnam?
No Vietnam.
Were you thinking about the kids? You told me this woman killed your children. Was this payback?
No payback.
Weren't you trying to get revenge, to take revenge for that?
No revenge.
Were you depressed?
No, no depression.
Angry?
No more anger.
But you drove your truck into their car?
I didn't kill them.
Then who killed them?
(he smiles for the first time) They killed themselves. 96. 91  97.
We see the PSYCHOLOGIST who interviewed Lester Farley wit his SUPERVISING DOCTOR; they have been watching a videota
Well?
Did you check the police report?
Yes.
(writing as he is talking) Were there any marks on Farley's truck that would indicate a collision with Silk's car?
No, but he could--
(he continues to write) Any signs on Coleman Silk's car that he was sideswiped by Farley's truck? The psychologist shakes his head.

(continuing; he looks up, smiles) Delusional. Lester Farley is completely delusional, but harmless. Continue with the regular outpatient treatment. Thorazine where indicated. As he closes Lester Farley's folder we CUT TO:
A path, leading from the place where Faunia' service was conducted toward the road. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH Faunia' mother and her husband (FAUNIA'S STEPFATHER) .
(agitated) But I'm her mother! If she kept a diary--
93 As they walk past THE CAMERA we see Nathan behind them, listening. Just then
So Faunia knew how to read.
It's filth!
But it's all I have left. Nathan catches up to them.
Excuse me, I wonder if I could have a word with--
(stiff) We're catching a plane.
(pressing on) Coleman Silk was a friend of mine and-- The following is all overlapping.
(growing angry) I told you we have no--
(raising his voice) He did not drive his car off the--
Listen to the man, Charles--
This is insane!
(to her husband) Stop pushing me,
It was your daughter's ex-husband. He killed them--
This woman is seriously ill--  99.
But you have her diary--
There is no diary. I have burned the diary. He takes his wife by the arm and they walk away we HOLD O NATHAN watching them.

Although, I knew beyond a shadow of a doubt that Lester Farley had murdered Coleman and Faunia; whatever proof I had was gone. What could I do about it? What should I do about it? We HEAR: BACH'S FUGUE in D MINOR -

By contrast to Faunia's funeral, Coleman's was stage managed to the nth degree by his family. This was to be Coleman's formal rehabilitation into the Athena College pantheon of heroes -and Coleman's children had spared no pains to get out the vote. They had even found a sacrificial lamb. PAN DOWN FROM to Herb Keeble as he mounts the pulpit. The is a beat of silence.

(quietly) My name is Herbert Keble. I am chairman of the Political Science Department - and I was among those who did not rise to Coleman's defense when he was accused of racism. Throughout this we CROSS CUT TO THE SILK PEW - where Coleman's children sit: Jeff, Mark (wearing a yarmulke) a Lisa in tears. We also see all the characters from the college we've met, from the couple who avoided Coleman outside the library, even a stoic Delphine Roux along wit Nelson Primus and his wife. And near the back Nathan Zuckerman off by himself, listening, watching.  94 95 100.

(continuing) "Coleman, I can't be with you on this." That is what I said, to my everlasting shame. Oh, I had my reasons. I thought I could help better behind the scenes. If I allied myself publicly, I told myself, I risked being labeled an Uncle Tom and thereby useless. I was wrong! I should never have said to my friend, "I can't be with you on this." I should have said, "I MUST be with you on this." I should have spoken up to say what I want to say now in the presence of his former colleagues and especially in the presence of his children: that the alleged misconduct never took place. Coleman Silk and his wife Iris were betrayed by the moral stupidity of a censorious, coercive community and I was a member of that community. We all were. Nathan looks around. People are crying.
The service is over, people drift away from the gravesite CLOSE ON TWO ADJOINING TOMBSTONES which read:

Nathan remains, lost in thought as people disappear aroun him. Only gradually is he aware... There's a WOMAN perhaps 62, still standing by the grave, primly holding her purse, a blank expression on her face. She is a light-skinned African American.
Mrs. Keble? (she looks at him) I believe your husband's eulogy changed everything today. The woman turns to him.  95 96 101.
I'm not Mrs. Keble. TIGHT ON NATHAN, as he slowly realizes -
You're...Are you Coleman's sister?
Nathan and Ernestine are sitting in the lounge of a quain country inn. TIGHT ON THE HAND OF A WAITER--as he serves them tea.
Lemon or milk?
Milk. (then: ) That day Walter told Coleman never to contact mother again - he froze everything forever.
Your mother obeyed Walter?

All the Silk men from my father on down are very decisive, Mr. Zuckerman. Yes, she did. But I didn't. I'd phone Coleman on his birthday, things like that... I was trying to reach him two days ago, his seventieth birthday... the day after he was killed. (realizes) I must have spoken to one of my nephews- (she looks away for a moment then regaining her composure) I don't blame Walter; he was trying to spare my mother more heartache.
Did he succeed?
When she died in the hospital, she was delirious. :
96 ERNESTINE (cont'd) She kept saying, "Oh nurse, get me to the train, I got a sick baby at home..." Over and over. Walter and I knew who that sick baby was.
Is Walter still alive?

Oh, yes. We're all a family of teachers, Mr. Zuckerman, imagine. Even Coleman's side of the family -I wish our parents had known that. And Walter was the first colored superintendant of schools in the state of New Jersey. (smiles) I guess you can tell what generation I am - I say "colored" and "Negro".
Did you know why your brother resigned from the college? ERNESTINE . I gather he was accused of racism. (smiles sadly) That beats all, doesn't it?
For using the word "spooks".

Sounds like from what I've heard today that anything is possible nowadays. People are just getting dumber - but more opinionated. The year I retired, youngsters were telling me that for Black History Month they would only read a biography of a black BY a black. What kind of silly idea is "Black History Month" anyway? If you're going to study Charles Drew, you do him when you do "science", don't segregate him in "Black History Month", for heavens sake.
I'm afraid I don't know who Charles Drew is.

Shame on you, Mr. Zuckerman. Dr. Charles Drew discovered how to prevent blood from clotting so it could be banked. Then he was injured in a car accident and the nearest hospital would not take colored, so he bled to death. Silence as Nathan contemplates this. She looks at him -

(continuing) You know what's sad, Mr. Zuckerman? Nowadays it's impossible to imagine anyone doing what my brother felt he had to do then... constructing his whole life around a lie. He could have stopped that racism charge in its tracks - I wonder if that solution even occurred to him. Tell me something, Mr. Zuckerman. Did he ever acknowledge what he'd done? To anyone? CLOSE ON NATHAN--He is silent for a long beat.
No, I don't think so. I don't think he did.
(a rueful smile) So he was Coleman until the end. Set out to do something and do it all the way. Even to the point of being buried as Jew. (sadly) Oh, Coleman... She stands; Nathan stands as well.
(continuing) Well, It's been quite a day... THE CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they start towards the door
Are you going to tell Walter?
Not unless he asks.  104.
What about Coleman's children?
It was for Coleman to tell them; not me.
97 98 But you told me.
No, you said, "You're Coleman's sister," and I admitted it. I'm not the one with something to hide.
(continuing; she extends a hand) Thank you for your hospitality...
May I come and visit you in New Jersey? I'd very much like to meet Walter.
Let me think about it... And she walks out the door.
Nathan driving carefully, lost in thought. Abruptly he re

head_text.subj: PARKED BY THE ROADSIDE, A SNOW-COVERED, RED

text: Nathan studies the car, slows down... Stops. Gets out - the middle of nowhere on a chilly twilight. Na walks around the truck, studying it... the murder weapon. On the rear bumper: MIA/POW... FOOTSTEPS in the SNOW lead into the woods... Nathan looks around, hesitates, decides to follow them...
SEVERAL ANGLES - Nathan making his way cautiously through whiteness of trees... until he comes out onto -  105.

As Nathan emerges from the woods, looking... NATHAN'S POV - a stunning vista of white... the LAKE is frozen over. No signs of civilization, but- In the middle of the lake, a lone FIGURE sits on an uptur yellow BUCKET, hunched over a HOLE in the ice, a fishing in his hands: LESTER, dressed in black wool CAP, pulled d over his forehead and ears... heavy overalls, boots, etc. Nathan doesn't move. But the FIGURE sees him. Now or neve Nathan's expression of fear and determination... CLOSE: NATHAN'S FOOT steps gingerly onto the ice. It HOLD Then his OTHER FOOT. The feet start walking... LOW POV - Nathan's FEET, the figure of Lester getting CLO Finally, Nathan's feet stop, twenty feet away from him...
(doesn't look up) You're on thin ice. The men look at one another.
I'd say we both are. Fish biting?

Not too good; not too bad... He glances away. Nathan does too and perceives several ne CIRCULAR HOLES dug randomly in the ice - AND A FOUR FOOT METAL SHAFT ending in a CORKSCREW BLADE: lethal-looking AUGER, rotated by the cranked handle on to Nathan's glance up from the deadly tool bumps into Les' e
Beautiful spot.
Why I'm here...
Peaceful.
Away from all the craziness. I'm out of it. (steals another glance) Long as I can keep it secret...  106.
True enough. Only now I know. Les glances up again, then back at his fishing line-
You look like a man who can keep a secret. Aren't you the writer?
What do you think about if the fish aren't biting? He doesn't answer for a moment, then -
I was thinking if I had a son he'd be out here with me now, fishing. That's what I was thinking when you walked out here. Thought you might have been my son.
Do you have a son?
No.
Never married? Another pause. Then, finally, he makes a face -

Doomed. (he jiggles the line) When I came back from Vietnam I couldn't relate to anybody. (looking around) Clean clothes, folks saying Hello, going to parties - I couldn't relate to it anymore. Used to get in my car and drive around. My buddies were afraid I was going to die in a car accident, they were-
Were you ever in a car accident?
(smiles) Wouldn't know if I was.
You still have PTSD? Post Traumatic Stress Disorder?
Well, I tend to isolate, don't I? What do you think I'm doing out here?
But no more car accidents...
There were never any accidents. Don't you listen?
And no kids.
Nope. You?
No.
Married?
No more.
So, you and me in the same boat. What kind of books you write?
I. write about people like you.
Is that so? What's the name of one of your books?
(hesitates) The Human Stain. It's not finished.
When it is, I'll buy it.
I'll send you a copy. What's your name?
Les Farley; send it care of Pete's Garage...

I will if you promise to read it. Les rises, putting down the fishing line and picking up t dreadful-looking corkscrew AUGER. As Nathan, transfixed with fear watches, Les brings it over to him, crunching ominously on the thin ice, holding it u Nathan's nose. Do we hear the ICE CRACKING under their combined weight? Nathan so Satisfied

I started ice fishing after my wife left me. All you have to do is dress warm and own the right equipment - like this auger. You drill a hole through the ice. This'1ll cut through just about anything - and drop your line with your favorite lure right through. frightened he can't speak -

(continuing) Any flash down there and the fish are attracted. They're sensitive to movement. The smallest vibration can alert them - even in the dark. And it's way dark down there... that Nathan is frightened, his tone changes -
(continuing) If I had a son, Little Les, a son of my own, I reckon I'd be teaching him all this stuff instead of you.
It's cold out here...
You better believe it.  109.
(taking a step backwards) I should be going...
But you know your ice fishing now, don't you? You can put it in your book... Nathan continues backing up, still facing Les and that DR
Don't worry - I will...
And you know my secret place here. You know everything now, don't you? But you won't tell, will you?
I hear you...
(a beat then) And, hey, Mr. Zuckerman. ON NATHAN--He freezes.
(continuing) What about the book?

You got it, it's in the mail. WIDE ANGLE (NATHAN'S POV): Les stands motionless on the i holding the auger, as Nathan slowly, cautiously, turns an walks back towards shore. Snow begins to fall and as we H ON LES FARLEY the snow grows thicker until the screen is white. We HOLD FOR A BEAT
This is the story of the tricky life and bitter downfall Coleman Silk. Nathan's VOICE mumbles the words over his typing...
